results.title: Rubber in today's world
results.brief_description: Reviews the history of rubber from its discovery to its use today as a basic commodity, including primitive methods of manufacture, improvements through vulcanisation, and modern production and process from plantation to market. Shows sources of and major steps in the production of synthetic rubber.

Shows sources of and major steps in the production of synthetic rubber.

results.title: The Roundabout
results.brief_description: Explains that traffic can flow in 16 different directions at an ordinary intersection. The roundabout is designed to bring streams of traffic together, mix them and send them on their right way. Conflicting streams of traffic in a roundabout all travel in the same direction, and reduce head-on collisions.

results.title: Roots of plants
results.brief_description: Various forms of roots are first presented. Time-lapse and micro-photography are employed to bring out the interesting processes of growth and the structure of the roots of plants. Animation is used to demonstrate osmosis.

results.title: Bertrand Russell discusses the role of the individual
results.brief_description: Lord Russell explains that he believes that important human advances have always been due to the activities of individuals. He discusses the relationship between the use of equipment to do important work and the loss of cultural and scientific freedom. He also comments on an orderly society with the maximum liberties of the individual. No other credits available.

results.title: Rockets: how they work
results.brief_description: Uses animated drawings and models to show how rockets achieve motion, and compares rocket power with other types of motive power. Scenes at a rocket launching site show the count-down procedure and the take-off of a giant multistage rocket. Demonstrates the functioning of a rocket guidance system.

results.title: The Rocket
results.creator_credit: William Pollard, Anthony Gilkison, Associated British-Pathe and Rayant Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates the progress of the rocket from a Chinese firecracker, through various 17th century inspirations for space travel, to its applications today. Shows scenes of Britain’s rocket research establishments; points out the part played rockets in World War II., and describes some American post-war experiments in rocket development.

results.title: The Robin
results.creator_credit: Donald Eastman, Rosemary Eastman and Gateway Educational Films
results.brief_description: A study of the robin and its relationship with man. Courtship behaviour, nest building and the rearing of young are shown in detail and the differences between migratory and non-migratory birds is explained.

results.title: Road to the West
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The story of the early days of Sydney Cove told by means of historical stills and by the re-enactment of the crossing of the Blue Mountains by Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson, the resulting development and relics of that period, including the old Court House at Hartley. Today fast transport enables commuters to travel to and from Sydney and the Blue Mountains in less than two hours, passing through towns named after the three explorers.

results.title: Road to independence
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
There is world-wide significance in the planned process by which Britain is helping her colonies master the art of self-government. This concluding film cites recent developments in Ghana, Nigeria, Nyasaland and other colonial territories where political evolution has seen striking progress in recent years. Edgar McInnis analyzes these developments on the basis of two main considerations; and why a ruling power should arrange for its own departure from its colonies; why, once independent, the former subjects should continue to associate with their former master.

results.title: River Murray
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Early settlers were plagued by flood and drought along the Murray, today the waters are controlled by the various dams, locks and canals which have been constructed along its course. Includes the Hume Reservoir, Mulwala Canal and the channel at Frenchman’s Creek. Now floodwaters are checked, dry lands irrigated, electric power is generated, useless land can be reclaimed, and the river is navigable from the mouth to a point just beyond Mildura. The film also considers the effect of this system on the development of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.
